revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Hans P. Kraus | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1907|10|12}} | birth_place = Vienna | death_date = {{death date and age|1988|11|01|1907|10|12}} | death_place = Ridgefield, Connecticut | nationality = Austrian-born | other_names = | known_for = Success as a rare book dealer | occupation = Rare book dealer }} '''Hans Peter Kraus''' (October 12, 1907 – November 1, 1988), also known as '''H. P. Kraus''' or '''HPK''', was an [[Austria]]n-born [[book dealer]] described as "without doubt the most successful and dominant rare book dealer in the world in the second half of the 20th century"<ref>William S. Reese, [http://www.reeseco.com/papers/abr19.htm The End of H.P. Kraus] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705104850/http://www.reeseco.com/papers/abr19.htm |date=2008-07-05 }}</ref> and in a league with other rare book dealers such as [[Bernard Quaritch]], [[Guillaume Debure|Guillaume de Bure]] and [[A.S.W. Rosenbach]]. Kraus specialized in medieval [[illuminated manuscripts]], [[incunabulum|incunables]] (books printed before 1501), and rare books of the 16th and 17th centuries, but would purchase and sell almost any book that came his way that was rare, valuable and important. He prided himself in being "the only bookseller in history...to have owned a [[Gutenberg Bible]] and the [[Psalter]]s of 1457 and 1459<ref>These are the two earliest psalters printed by Gutenberg's successors, [[Johann Fust]] and [[Peter Schoeffer]]. See Margaret Stillwell, 'The Beginning of the World of Books', 1450 to 1470, nos. 18 & 27.</ref> simultaneously," stressing that "'own' here is the correct word, as they were bought not for a client's account but for stock."<ref>H.P.Kraus, ''A Rare Book Saga'', [[G.P. Putnam's Sons]], New York (1978) (hereinafter "RBS") p. 227. {{ISBN|0-399-12064-5}}.</ref>
==Early life and career== Kraus was born on October 12, 1907, in [[Vienna]]. After working for R. Lechner in Vienna and Ernst Wasmuth in [[Berlin]], he started his own rare book business in 1932, which prospered despite the [[Great Depression|Depression]]. In 1938, after the [[Nazi Germany|German]] [[Anschluss|annexation of Austria]], Kraus was arrested for being Jewish and sent to the [[Dachau concentration camp]]. After several months, he was transferred to [[Buchenwald concentration camp|Buchenwald]]. After eight months in Buchenwald, he was released, returned to Vienna and ordered to leave Austria within two months.<ref>RBS, pp. 59-72. Kraus does not explain in his autobiography exactly how he came to be released.</ref>
Kraus abandoned his business and stock of 100,000 books, although he had previously shipped some books and valuables to [[Switzerland]], and traveled to [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]. He arranged to have his mother join him there; she arrived just two days before [[World War II]] began. In September he obtained a visa and sailed for [[New York City]], arriving on October 12, 1939, where he arrived with the 1494 Vérard Columbus letter gaining him his first piece of publicity as a bookdealer in America: a newspaper column on the Columbus letter arriving on Columbus Day.<ref>''The Kraus Saga'', The Book Collector, 1983, p.137</ref> Within two weeks of arrival, he met Hanni Zucker, also from Vienna, whom he subsequently married.<ref>RBS, pp. 73-82.</ref>
==Bookseller extraordinaire== Kraus restarted his rare book business in New York, which soon began to prosper. His first important sale was to [[Lessing J. Rosenwald]], a major book collector, who ultimately donated his collection of early printed books to the [[Library of Congress]].<ref>RBS, p. 85.</ref> Over the years, Kraus bought and sold major medieval illuminated manuscripts, incunables and assorted rare books and manuscripts. Among his most important sales were the [[Anhalt Gospels]],<ref>RBS, pp. 139-140.</ref> the finely illuminated [[Hours of Catherine of Cleves]] now reunited with its other half at the [[Morgan Library]], the Arthur Houghton copy of the Gutenberg Bible for $2.5 million,<ref>RBS, pp. 236-137.</ref> three copies of [[William Caxton|Caxton]]'s first edition of the Canterbury Tales,<ref>RBS, p. 246.</ref> and the original manuscript of the proclamation of the [[Louisiana Purchase]], signed by [[Thomas Jefferson]],<ref>RBS, p. 216.</ref> He also purchased the enigmatic [[Voynich manuscript]] in 1961 for $24,500, and after seven years of unsuccessfully attempting to sell it for as much as $160,000 ultimately donated it to the [[Beinecke Library]] at [[Yale University]].<ref>RBS pp. 218-222.</ref> Kraus also sold the magnificent manuscript [[Giant Bible of Mainz]] to Lessing J. Rosenwald who donated it the Library of Congress.<ref>RBS, p. 122.</ref>
Early in his career, Kraus initiated a practice of buying up entire libraries or collections at a discounted price and then selling the items individually or in smaller groups, carefully researched and catalogued, for a great profit.<ref>RBS, pp.40, 45-50, 77, 105.</ref> He continued that practice after he moved to the United States, for example, buying in 1949 some 20,000 volumes of the [[Prince Liechtenstein]] library for a "rock bottom" price,<ref>RBS, pp. 151-156.</ref> the entire [[Frederick Baldwin Adams, Jr.|Frederick Adams]] collection of early communist, radical and anarchistic literature and ephemera,<ref>RBS, pp. 157-165.</ref> and in 1977 the remainder of the great manuscript collection of the 19th-century bibliomaniac [[Sir Thomas Phillipps]], which after the better part of a century of auction sales, still consisted of 2,000 manuscript volumes and 130,000 manuscript letters and documents.<ref>RBS, p. 226.</ref>
==Pre-dating the Gutenberg Bible?== In 1952, Kraus purchased a copy of an extremely rare incunabula, the [[Constance Missal]], then known in only two copies. Bearing no date, it was printed with type nearly identical to, but seemingly more primitive than, that used in the 1457 and 1459 Psalters, and some scholars believed that it might be the first printed book, pre-dating the Gutenberg Bible. Kraus sold it as a major bibliographical prize to the [[Morgan Library]]. Several years later, [[Allan Stevenson]], by a brilliant and painstaking comparison of the different states of wear in the watermarks in the Constance Missal with those in dated books, conclusively established that it was printed in 1473, nearly 20 years after the Gutenberg Bible.<ref>Allan Stevenson, ''The Problem of the Missale Speciale'', London, 1967.</ref> Despite the definitive proof to the contrary, Kraus still professed that, "Speaking for myself, I believe that the Constance Missal is earlier than the Gutenberg Bible."<ref>RBS, p. 229.</ref>
==Sale catalogs== Kraus regularly issued printed catalogs of books for sale, which contained extensive detailed descriptions of the books and manuscripts. Totaling at least 223,<!-- This is the most recent I can find, it's called England/Ireland/Scotland/Wales. --> they are prized today as reference works. Some of the catalogs contained full color illustrations of bindings and illustrations, and a few were issued hardbound. Kraus had "the largest and most complete reference library of books on the subject of bibliography ever put together by a book dealer anywhere."<ref>Selby Kieffer, quoted in Wendy Moonan [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9802EFDD1438F937A25752C1A9659C8B63 "Time to Write Finis For a Book Trove"]</ref>
==Businessman and collector== Kraus quite understandably was very proud of his success as a businessman, amassing a fortune from the rare book and manuscript trade. He described his "philosophy of success in business" as: "Push on, hit hard, follow through."<ref>RBS, p. 36.</ref> Besides being the only dealer to own, as inventory, the Gutenberg Bible and the 1457 and 1459 Psalters at the same time, he "owned most of the major incunabula,"<ref>RBS, p. 227</ref> and "bought and sold more Caxtons than any other living bookseller."<ref>RBS, pp. 245-246.</ref> His autobiography is full of stories where he bought some rare manuscript or book at a low price and turned around and sold it for a much greater price. He also lamented a number of instances where he narrowly failed to secure some book or collection including some of the [[Dead Sea Scrolls]],<ref>RBS, p. 127-128.</ref> or where he sold a very rare item too cheaply.
Kraus acknowledged that his autobiography might leave the reader with "the impression that [he was] interested only in making money."<ref>RBS, p. 373.</ref> However, he had a deep love of books and was himself a serious collector. One area of particular interest for Kraus was books relating to [[Francis Drake|Sir Francis Drake]]. He eventually wrote a biography of Drake, based on materials in his collection, a collection that he later donated to the Library of Congress.<ref>RBS pp. 344-349. See also [http://memory.loc.gov/intldl/drakehtml/rbdkoverview.html The Sir Francis Drake Collection] and [http://international.loc.gov/intldl/drakehtml The Kraus Collection of Sir Francis Drake.]</ref> Kraus also put together a collection of important manuscripts concerning colonial [[New Spain|Spanish America]], particularly Mexico, including a letter from [[Amerigo Vespucci]]. Kraus donated that collection to the Library of Congress in 1969.<ref>RBS pp. 361-366. See also [https://www.loc.gov/rr/mss/coll/139.html Hans P. Kraus Collection; Documents relating to colonial Spanish America.] and [http://lcweb2.loc.gov/service/mss/eadxmlmss/eadpdfmss/2004/ms004019.pdf A Register of the Collection.]</ref>
In 1978 Kraus published his autobiography ''A Rare Book Saga''.
==Journals and reprints== Over the years, Kraus purchased large collections of technical and academic journals, which he was able to resell to libraries at great profit.<ref>RBS, pp. 48, 77, 101-103.</ref> In New York, he opened a second business, Kraus Periodicals Inc., to specialize in the sale of runs of scholarly journals, and soon made an en bloc purchase of over 300,000 issues.<ref>RBS, pp. 102-103.</ref> Later, after he had received multiple orders for the same journals, Kraus formed a business that reprinted scientific and scholarly journals and reference books.<ref>RBS, pp. 367-372.</ref>
==End of the business== Kraus died on November 1, 1988, in [[Ridgefield, Connecticut]], after which the business was carried on by his widow Hanni and their daughter and son-in-law, Mary Ann and Roland Folter.<ref>"H.P. Kraus, Internationally Prominent Rare Book Dealer", ''AB Bookman's Weekly'' (Mar. 20, 1989) pp. 1284-1285.</ref> The business subsequently closed, and its remaining inventory and reference works were sold by [[Sotheby's]].<ref>William S. Reese, [http://www.reeseco.com/papers/abr19.htm The End of H.P. Kraus] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705104850/http://www.reeseco.com/papers/abr19.htm |date=2008-07-05 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Works== *[https://www.loc.gov/rr/rarebook/catalog/drake/ Sir Francis Drake: A Pictorial Biography by Hans P. Kraus] Online presentation for the Collections at the [[Library of Congress]]
==External links== * Video on the end of his business and his reference library [http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/179756-1] * [https://www.loc.gov/rr/rarebook/coll/kraus.html Hans P. and Hanni Kraus Collection of Sir Francis Drake] From the Collections at the [[Library of Congress]]
==Further reading== * H. P. Kraus, "On book collecting: the story of my Drake library". The [[James Ford Bell Lecture]], no. 6. [Minneapolis]: The Associates of the [[James Ford Bell Library]], 1969. * Ernst J. Grube, ''Islamic Paintings from the 11th to the 18th Century in the Collection of Hans P. Kraus''. * J. Benedict Warren, ''Hans P. Kraus Collection of Hispanic American Manuscripts''. * [[Hellmut Lehmann-Haupt]], ed., ''Homage to a Bookman. Essays on Manuscripts, Books and Printing Written for Hans P. Kraus'', Berlin, 1967. (A [[festschrift]] in honor of Hans P. Kraus.)
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kraus, Hans P.}} [[Category:1907 births]] [[Category:1988 deaths]] [[Category:Austrian Jews]] [[Category:American bibliographers]] [[Category:American booksellers]] [[Category:American people of Austrian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Austrian bibliographers]] [[Category:Austrian booksellers]] [[Category:Austrian businesspeople]] [[Category:Austrian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Book and manuscript collectors]] [[Category:Businesspeople from New York City]] [[Category:Writers from Vienna]] [[Category:Dachau concentration camp survivors]] [[Category:Buchenwald concentration camp survivors]] [[Category:20th-century American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]]

{{ infobox person | name = Jean-François Dubos | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|9|2|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Cabourg]], [[France]] | nationality = [[France|French]] | education = [[University of Paris]] | occupation = Businesspeople }}
'''Jean-François Dubos''' (born 2 September 1945) is a former French businessman who was Chairman of the Management board of the multinational media conglomerate [[Vivendi]].
==Biography==
===Education=== Jean-François Dubos has a degree in [[English language|English]] and [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and holds a graduate degree in public international law and political science from the [[University of Paris]].<ref>[http://lentreprise.lexpress.fr/gestion-entreprise/jean-francois-dubos-un-amateur-de-musique-classique-au-sommet-de-vivendi_33689.html]</ref>
===Career=== From 1981 to 1984, he was co-head of the cabinet of the French [[Department of Defence (France)|Ministry of Defense]], under [[Charles Hernu]]. From 1984 to 1991, he was a member of the French Administrative Supreme Court (Conseil d’Etat). Jean-François Dubos joined [[Compagnie Générale des Eaux]], the predecessor of Vivendi, as deputy to the Chief Executive Officer in 1991, and since 1994, has held the position of General Counsel. He was appointed Chairman of the Management Board of Vivendi at a Supervisory Board held on June 28, 2012.<ref>[http://www.ouest-france.fr/actu/actuLocale_-Jean-Francois-Dubos-de-Cabourg-a-Vivendi_40790-2091709------14220-aud_actu.Htm]</ref>
===Head of Vivendi=== Since his appointment as Vivendi Chairman, Jean-François Dubos has operated a reorientation of the group's strategy toward Media and Telecommunications.<ref>[http://www.latribune.fr/technos-medias/medias/20130226trib000751085/vivendi-tente-un-virage-dans-les-medias-au-detriment-des-telecoms.html, La Tribune]</ref>
According to him, "the future of Vivendi is to be found in content and content distribution". He believes Vivendi will become these sectors' European leaders.<ref>[http://www.lesechos.fr/16/12/2012/lesechos.fr/0202452574406_jean-francois-dubos-----l-avenir-de-vivendi-est-dans-les-contenus-et-leur-distribution-.htm, Les Echos]</ref>
During the June 24, 2014 Annual Shareholders Meeting, he became the Honorary Chairman of the company.<ref>[http://www.vivendi.com/vivendi-en/governance/supervisory-board/]</ref>
==Notes and references== <references/>
{{start box}} {{s-bus}} {{succession box | before = [[Jean-Bernard Lévy]] | title = CEO of [[Vivendi]] | years = 2012-2014 | after = [[Arnaud de Puyfontaine]] }} {{end box}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dubos, Jean-Francois}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Paris alumni]]

page.title: List of Main Street Programs in the United States

revision.comment: Added a missing main street district under the Florida section.
revision.text:
{{More citations needed| date=September 2012}} {{directory|date=September 2018}} '''Main Street Programs''' aim to revitalize their downtowns and commercial districts through preservation-based economic development and community revitalization. The project commenced in 1977 with a pilot involving 3 towns: [[Galesburg, Illinois]], [[Madison, Indiana]], and [[Hot Springs, South Dakota]].<ref>{{cite web|title=History of the National Main Street Center|url=http://www.preservationnation.org/main-street/about-main-street/the-center/history.html|website=Main Street America|accessdate=30 April 2016}}</ref> Since then, the program has been expanded to include many other towns. These may be statewide or regional "coordinating programs" or "local programs." Programs determined to be "Designated" follow best-practices established by the National Main Street Center and/or statewide or regional coordinating programs. A [[main street manager]] is appointed to implement the program locally.
==Alabama== No designated programs
==Alaska== No designated programs
==Arizona== *[[Apache Junction, Arizona|Apache Junction]], Apache Junction Main Street (D) *[[Buckeye, Arizona|Buckeye]], Buckeye Main Street(D) *[[Casa Grande, Arizona|Casa Grande]], Casa Grande Main Street(D) *[[Florence, Arizona|Florence]], Florence Main Street Program (D) *[[Globe, Arizona|Globe]], Globe Main Street Program (D) *[[Lake Havasu City, Arizona|Lake Havasu City]], Main Street Uptown Association (D) *[[Nogales, Arizona|Nogales]], Nogales Community Development Corporation (D) *[[Payson, Arizona|Payson]], Payson Main Street Program (D) *[[Pinetop-Lakeside, Arizona|Pinetop-Lakeside]], Pinetop-Lakeside Main Street (D) *[[Prescott, Arizona|Prescott]], Prescott Main Street (D) *[[Safford, Arizona|Safford]], Safford Main Street (D) *[[Sedona, Arizona|Sedona]], Sedona Main Street Program (D) *[[Show Low, Arizona|Show Low]], Show Low Main Street, Inc. (D) *[[Williams, Arizona|Williams]], Williams Main Street Association, Inc. (D) *[[Yuma, Arizona|Yuma]], Yuma Main Street Program (D)

revision.comment: /* Contact dispensing */ ce
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=July 2008}} {{confusing|date=July 2008}} }} '''Microdispensing''' is the technique of producing liquid media dosages in volumes of less than one microlitre. The continuing miniaturization in almost all technical areas creates constant challenges for industry, development and research facilities. Microdispensing is one of those challenges. Ever smaller amounts of adhesive, liquid, oil, grease and a multitude of other media must be dispensed reliably and accurately in dosage and placement with short cycle times. The precise positioning and quantity of fluids such as glue, reagents or any other substance has a great influence on the overall quality of a medical device. A few examples are: * Micro-dosing systems with a quantity as small as 50 picolitres * Volumetric systems for use with adhesives and spraying systems for silicone coating needles and other surfaces Microdispensing is also used in non-medical applications, like on-demand soda flavoring (the [[Coca-Cola Freestyle]] and [[Pepsi Spire]]), [[inkjet printing]], and [[3-D printing]]. ==Dispensing techniques== There are two basic types of dispensing techniques: classic contact dispensing and non-contact dispensing. ===Contact dispensing=== In contact dispensing, the drop forms at the exit of a nozzle, and is deposited by contact, while the drop is still on the nozzle. The technique is as old as the wish to divide a medium, stored in a big container, into smaller amounts. A good example for this is applying adhesive with a tube: To apply the adhesive requires contact between the tip of the tube and the part for the bead of adhesive to be transferred. This method has disadvantages: * Slow dispensing * Part has to be touched * Part could be damaged * Adhesive forms threads * Adhesive is not in the expected place * Adhesive amounts are difficult to reproduce Despite all of these disadvantages, contact dispensing is still used in the majority of automated processes today, because of: * A lack of knowledge regarding non-contact dispensing systems * Few manufacturers for non-contact dispensing systems * No direct access to dispensing area (e.g. undercuts) * Medium can not be dispensed without contact * Dispensing without stress to Medium is possible * More precise dispensing especially at bead dispensing * Simple to clean in most cases ===Typical technologies for contact dispensing=== Gear pump * high-frequency pulsation * high performance * always valves * no solids possible Pressure-time systems * many components * pragmatic evaluation of quantity and control * add. power source: air * volume flow depends on pressure, time and temperature ===Non-contact dispensing (Jetting)=== In non-contact dispensing, the drop also forms at the end of a nozzle, but far enough away from the target area that the drop separates from the nozzle before it hits. This, too, is a very old technique, as old as squirting liquid from a tube. Because of increasing requirements in regards to cycle time and accuracy in almost all areas of production, non-contact dispensing is constantly gaining importance. A good example for this is the attachment of very small electronic parts (SMD parts) onto printed circuit boards and substrates. For this, the part carrier only needs to be positioned in one plane - after that the adhesive can be transferred without contact. The following examples show the advantages of non-contact dispensing: * Removal of a feed motion to the part * Time saving through ejection of adhesive * No contact with part (no damage) * Even spread of adhesive topography independent of part topography and surface structure Non-contact dispensing can be divided in two different methods: * Jet-forming dispensing * Dynamic drop dispensing ==Jet-forming dispensing==
Jet-forming dispensing exists when the flow velocity of a medium at the nozzle exit is high enough that the effects of gravitation and surface tension on the separation of the fluid from the nozzle are of secondary importance. This state is characterized by the [[Weber number]]: :\mathrm{We} = \frac{\rho v^2 D}{\sigma} where {| |- |\rho||: Fluid [[density]] ([[kilogram|kg]]/[[meter|m]]3) |- |v||: Jet [[velocity]] (m/[[second|s]]) |- |D||: Nozzle diameter (m) |- |\sigma||: [[Surface tension]] ([[newton (unit)|N]]/m) |} The physical border line between drop- and jet-forming is around a Weber-number of 8. At this point the dynamic pressure of the flowing medium exceeds the pressure from the surface tension of the drop, which therefore sticks to the nozzle. This transitional stage can be demonstrated at a water tap by gradually increasing the flow, going from the dropping status until a continuous water jet has formed. The Weber-number in this case is, however, clearly above 8, because of the jet exit conditions of the nozzle. By using the Weber-number, the theoretical lower limit of the mass flow can be found for the jet-forming conditions. In actual applications, to assure a safe dispensing process, the real Weber-numbers chosen should be between 20 and 50. For a calculated estimation of the fluid flow velocity in the nozzle, for fluids with Newtonian flow behavior, the formula for capillary fluid flow according to the [[Hagen–Poiseuille law]] has been proven. :Q = \frac{\Delta P \pi r^4}{8 \mu L} {| |Q||: Volumetric flow rate |- |\Delta P||: Pressure difference between nozzle entrance and nozzle exit |- |r||: Nozzle radius |- |\mu||: Dynamic viscosity |- |L||: Length of the nozzle |} To avoid atomizing of the fluid at the nozzle exit, the fluid flow in the nozzle must be laminar, which is the case as long as the [[Reynolds number]] (Re) of the nozzle is smaller than the [[Reynolds number#Transition and turbulent flow|critical Reynolds-number]] of the nozzle: : Re < Re_{crit} Reynolds-number of the nozzle: : Re = \frac{\rho v D}{\mu} {| |\mu||: Dynamic viscosity |} Critical Reynolds-number of the nozzle: : 1800 \lessapprox Re_{crit} \lessapprox 2400 Thus, the theoretical range of the jet-forming dispension is enclosed at its lower limit by the Weber-number and at its upper limit by the critical Reynolds-number. For practical applications, a high kinetic energy in the fluid jet is not desirable, because the jet probably would burst and spatter tiny droplets around the target point. Jet-forming dispensing systems are therefore usually operated in the area of lower Weber-numbers. In practice, the calculation of the Weber-number becomes more complicated when fluids with additives are used, which demonstrate a non-Newtonian (i.e. thixotropic) flow behavior and therefore the viscosity during the flow through the nozzle is different. ==Dynamic drop dispensing==
Dynamic drop dispensing is characterised by separation of a drop from the nozzle exit through a dynamic process, because the static pressure of the liquid medium is insufficient for forming a fluid jet. A well-known example is [[inkjet printing]]. In this application, the volume of a small dispensing chamber with adjoining nozzle becomes reduced through a short impulse, whereby the ink is ejected through the nozzle. Nozzle chamber, nozzle and ink reservoir are hereby fluidically connected without any valve in between. During the dispensing process, some of the medium is also flowing in the reverse direction (back into the reservoir). The surface tension of the fluid at the nozzle exit prevents air being sucked in and fluid from exiting the nozzle when the dispensing chamber is filled up again. The principle of this process is only useful for low-viscosity fluids and this principle is not applicable with higher fluid pressures. Ink-jet systems have the following inherent properties: • Very small single-drop volumes are achievable (8 picolitres)
• High dispensing frequencies can be realised (some kHz)
• Low costs for mass production
• Only certain low-viscosity media are dispensable (i.e. no volatile media)
• Principally not leak-proof For industrial production, the dispensing amounts and the range of viscosity spectra of ink-jet systems for most applications are too small. In these fields of production, specially-designed valves with tappet drives of high dynamic are used instead. These microdispensing systems are characterised by the following properties: • Single drop volumes from 10 to 200 nanolitres
• Dispensing frequencies up to 100 Hz
• Dispensing accuracy < 1%
• Media viscosities up to 200 Pa·s (thixotropic) ==References== {{reflist}} * This article uses material from [http://www.liquidyn.com/ Liquidyn.com] [[Category:Routes of administration]] [[Category:Drug delivery devices]] [[Category:Industrial processes]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=September 2018}}
'''Multi-Modal Logistics Parks (MMLPs)''' are a key policy initiative of the [[Government of India]] to improve the country’s logistics sector by lowering overall freight costs, reducing vehicular pollution and congestion, and cutting warehousing costs. The government’s [[Ministry of Road Transport and Highways]] (MoRTH) is developing multi-modal logistics parks at selected locations in the country under its Logistics Efficiency Enhancement Program (LEEP).<ref>IANS. 2017. Government to develop 15 multi-modal logistics parks for Rs 33,000 cr. Business Standard. 16 May. <nowiki>https://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/government-to-develop-15-multi-modal-logistics-parks-for-rs-33-000-cr-117051501161_1.html</nowiki></ref> India is burdened with high logistics costs, which account for about 13% of the value of goods sold in the economy compared with 8% in other major economies. The average cost to export/import one container in India is about 72% higher than in China.<ref name=":0">R. Arora. 2017. Government Approves Plan to Build 34 Mega Multi-Modal Logistics Parks at an Investment of Rs2 Lakh Cr. The Economic Times. 21 July. <nowiki>https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/economy/infrastructure/government-approves-plan-to-build-34-mega-multi-modal-logistics-parks-at-an-investment-of-rs-2-lakh-cr/articleshow/59690653.cms</nowiki></ref>
LEEP, which is spearheaded by the MoRTH and the [[National Highways Authority of India]] (NHAI), aims to enhance freight transport in India by reducing costs and time, and improving the tracking and traceability of consignments through infrastructural, procedural, and information technology interventions.<ref name=":1">Government of India, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways. 2016. Logistics Efficiency Enhancement Program (LEEP). Delhi.</ref>
The government defines an MMLP as a freight-handling facility encompassing a minimum area of 100 acres (40.5 hectares), with various modes of transport access, and comprising mechanized warehouses, specialized storage solutions such as cold storage, facilities for mechanized material handling and inter-modal transfer container terminals, and bulk and break-bulk cargo terminals.<ref>Government of India, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways. 2017. Draft Policy Document: Development of Multimodal Logistics Parks. Delhi.</ref> Logistics parks will further provide value-added services such as customs clearance with bonded storage yards, quarantine zones, testing facilities, and warehousing management services. Provisions will also be made for late-stage manufacturing activities such as kitting and final assembly, grading, sorting, labelling and packaging activities, re-working, and returns management (Arora, 2017).
== Background == Keeping pace with India’s rapid economic growth is the expansion of the country’s logistics sector. The movement of freight in the country nearly doubled to around 2,300 billion ton-kilometers in fiscal year 2015 from 1,200 billion ton-kilometers in fiscal year 2008.<ref>A ton-kilometer is a unit of transport measurement equivalent to moving 1 ton of cargo a distance of 1 kilometer.</ref> The government expects freight movement in the country to continue its growth trajectory, with expected annual growth of 8%–10% over the next 10 years. The logistics sector as a whole, according to a study commissioned by MoRTH, is poised to expand at roughly 1.2 times the rate of India’s gross domestic product growth through 2032, by which time it is expected to generate $360 billion in value added, up from $115 billion in 2017.<ref>H.Y. Jeong. 2017. What Multimodal Parks Can Do for Logistics in India. 27 September. <nowiki>https://blogs.adb.org/blog/what-multimodal-parks-can-do-logistics-india</nowiki></ref>
In 2016, India managed to improve its performance in the [[Logistics Performance Index]] (LPI), a ranking published by the [[World Bank]] to measure the logistics performance of countries.<ref>The World Bank. 2016. Connecting to Compete 2016: Trade Logistics in the Global Economy—The Logistics Performance Index and Its Indicators. Washington: The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development/The World Bank.</ref> India’s LPI ranking rose to 35th in 2016, up from 46th in 2012. India’s ranking, however, still lags behind some of its economic peers, including other Asian countries. The best logistics performer in Asia is Singapore, which was ranked 5th in 2016, followed by Hong Kong, China (9th); Japan (12th); the Republic of Korea (24th); and the People’s Republic of China (PRC) (27th). Among the grouping of so-called [[BRICS]]—comprising Brazil, Russia, India, the PRC, and South Africa—aside from the PRC, South Africa also outperformed India in 2016 with a ranking of 20th (World Bank, 2016).
However, there remain significant challenges to the sector’s development. Logistics costs are high in India relative to costs in developed countries. Logistics costs as a percentage of gross domestic product stood at approximately 13% in 2015. In comparison, the logistics cost in developed countries is approximately 8%–10%. In more specific terms, India’s road freight cost per ton-kilometer, adjusted for purchasing power parity, is ₹1.90 ($0.03), which is almost double that of the United States.<ref>Government of India, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways. 2017. Concept Note: Logistics Efficiency Enhancement Program (LEEP)—Development of Multimodal Logistics Parks. Delhi.</ref>
Higher logistics costs in India are primarily driven by five key factors.<ref name=":1" /> One is an unfavorable inter-modal mix, with 60% of freight movement skewed toward road transport despite the lower freight cost of rail transport. Second is India’s inefficient fleet mix, which is characterized by smaller, inefficient trucks. Third is the underdeveloped material handling infrastructure that is characterized by a fragmented industry consisting largely of small, unorganized warehouses with limited mechanization. Fourth is the underdeveloped road infrastructure with a limited presence of 4- and 6-lane national highways. Lastly, the lack of a national logistics policy, institutional and regulatory bottlenecks, such as complicated documentation and procedures related to toll collections, adversely impact logistics costs in India.<ref name=":1" />
== Government policy initiatives == Along with its initial efforts, including the [[Make in India]] program and improvements in infrastructure, Government of India has made a number of decisions aimed at transforming the country’s logistics sector. According to R. Goyal and S. Singh, adviser and young professional in the infrastructure–connectivity vertical section of [[NITI Aayog]], the government is committed towards an integrated development of logistics sector through policy amendments, infrastructural development, tax reforms and technology adoption.<ref>R. Goyal and S. Singh. 2018. Indian Logistics Sector: On the Path of Transformation. Government of India, NITI Aayog (National Institution for Transforming India). <nowiki>http://niti.gov.in/content/indian-logistics-sector-path-transformation</nowiki></ref>
These decisions include the nationwide imposition of a goods and services tax (GST), which came into effect 1 July 2017. This levy on the supply of goods and services, which replaced many indirect tax laws that previously existed in India, should expedite the conversion of informal logistics operations into formal ones and speed up freight movement at interstate borders as check posts are dismantled. The government further established a new logistics division in the Department of Commerce to coordinate integrated development of the sector via policy changes, improvement in existing procedures, identification of bottlenecks and gaps, and introduction of technology-based interventions. The [[Ministry of Commerce and Industry (India)|Ministry of Commerce and Industry]] is aiming to develop an integrated logistics portal to connect buyers, logistics service providers and relevant government agencies. The logistics sector has been reclassified by the government with its inclusion under the Harmonized Master List of Infrastructure Subsector. With this, the logistics sector can access long-term credit, the approval process for the construction of MMLPs is simplified, and investments by debt and pension funds into recognized logistics projects would be encouraged by the regulated sector’s market accountability (Goyal & Singh, 2018).
== Purpose and design == The development of MMLPs is envisaged as a key policy measure to reduce logistics costs and help address three of the five constraining issues identified above. Specifically, these include an unfavorable modal mix, inefficient fleet mix, and underdeveloped material handling infrastructure. In July 2017, the Government of India approved a plan to build 35 MMLPs. State governments will provide the land needed for the projects, which will then be taken up through public–private partnerships.<ref name=":0" />
According to MoRTH, these MMLPs are expected to serve five key functions: freight aggregation and distribution, multi-modal freight transport, integrated storage and warehousing, information technology support, and value-added services. [[File:The_Effective_Framework_for_a_Multi-Modal_Logistics_Park_Development.jpg|alt=|center|frameless|600x600px]]
== ADB role and support == In 2017, the Government of India launched a program to develop 35 multi-modal logistics parks across the country over the succeeding years and invited [[Asian Development Bank]] (ADB) to become a lead partner and provide the necessary support (Jeong, 2017). ADB then conducted a pre-feasibility study to assess the suitability of MMLP locations and identify the requisite infrastructure, connectivity, and regulatory reforms in two selected locations: [[Bangalore|Bengaluru]] in Karnataka and [[Guwahati]] in Assam.
In this regard, the state government identified Dabaspete as the site for the park for Bengaluru in Karnataka. Bengaluru is ideally located for an MMLP in south India, with good connections via rail and road networks, and proximity to 17 million potential consumers in Chennai. ADB sees the Bengaluru MMLP as having the potential to become a model for other multimodal logistics parks in India. ADB also supported the pre-feasibility study for a MMLP in [[Jogighopa]], Assam, which incorporates rail, road, and inland-waterway connectivity. The proposed site is located along [[National Waterway 2]] and on the Indo-Bangladesh road route, making it suitable for the MMLP with multi modal access.<ref>K. Rathi. 2018. Multimodal logistics park: Re-defining infrastructure in India. Qrius.com (formerly The Indian Economist). 21 February. <nowiki>https://qrius.com/multimodal-logistics-park-redefining-infrastructure-india/</nowiki></ref>
== See also == * [[Logistics Performance Index]] * [[Ministry of Road Transport and Highways]] * [[National Highways Authority of India]] * [[Make in India]]
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://blogs.adb.org/blog/what-multimodal-parks-can-do-logistics-india Asian Development Blog: What Multimodal Parks Can Do for Logistics in India] * [http://www.makeinindia.com/home Make in India] * [http://barakaconsult.com/uploads/Concept%20Note%20-%20Logistics%20Efficiency%20Enhancement%20Program%20(LEEP)%20on%20Development%20of%20Multimodal%20Logistics.pdf Concept Note: Logistics Efficiency Enhancement Program (LEEP)—Development of Multimodal Logistics Parks] * [http://indiaonthego.in/pdf/Logistic-Parks-Policy.pdf Draft Policy Document: Development of Multimodal Logistics Parks] * [http://morth.nic.in/showfile.asp?lid=2144&key=voluntary%20vehicle%20fleet&n=1 Concept Note: Voluntary Vehicle Fleet Modernization Program ] * [http://indiaonthego.in/ India Integrated Transport and Logistics Summit 2017]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{infobox person |name=Nitun Kundu |image=Nitun Kundu's photo.jpg |native_name=নিতুন কুন্ডু |native_name_lang = bn |birth_place=[[Dinajpur District, Bangladesh|Dinajpur district]], [[Bengal Presidency]], [[British India]] (now [[Bangladesh]]) |death_place=[[Dhaka]], Bangladesh |awards=[[Ekushey Padak]] |occupation=Sculptor, painter and entrepreneur |birth_date={{birth date|df=y|1935|12|3}} |death_date={{death date and age|df=y|2006|9|15|1935|12|3}} }}
'''Nitya Gopal Kundu''' (3 December 1935 – 15 September 2006) was a Bangladeshi artist, sculptor and entrepreneur. He founded the furniture company [[Otobi]].<ref name=pass>{{cite news |date=16 September 2015 |title=Artist Nitun Kundu passes away |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/2006/09/16/d6091601044.htm |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]]}}</ref>
==Early life== Kundu was born in [[Dinajpur District, Bangladesh|Dinajpur district]] to his parents Gnanendranath Kundu and Binapani Kundu. He was the fourth among seven siblings. Kundu was married to Phalguni Kundu and had a daughter Amity and a son Animesh.
==Education and early career== Kundu graduated from Dhaka Art College (now the Institute of Fine Arts) in 1959.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hossain |first1=Takir |title=Liberation War in art |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=118388 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> In the years leading up to 1971, he worked at the [[United States Information Agency|United States Information Service]] (USIS) in [[Dhaka]] designing exhibits and graphics.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Kristula |first=Michael |date=December 2012 |title=Nitun Kundu: A Success |url=http://www.afsa.org/sites/default/files/flipping_book/1212/files/assets/seo/page34.html |journal=Foreign Service Journal |page=34 |access-date=8 November 2015}}</ref>
==Liberation War== During the [[Bangladesh Liberation War]], Kundu worked with the artist [[Quamrul Hassan]] at the public relations department of the Bangladesh Government-in-Exile at [[Mujibnagar]]. In collaboration with Hassan and a group of notable artists namely [[Debdas Chakraborty]], Nasir Biswas, Pranesh Mandal and Biren Shome; Kundu worked on numerous posters and works of art aimed at arousing the newly formed [[Mukti Bahini]] liberation army and also raising awareness of the genocide being unleashed by the [[Pakistan Army]] on the people of Bangladesh.
It was during this period he designed two posters which became among the most recognized<ref name="Nitun Kundu: Our role model">{{cite news |title=Nitun Kundu: Our role model |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=202741 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> works of art produced during the war. They were titled ''Sada Jagrata Banglar Mukti Bahini'' and ''Banglar Hindu, Banglar Bouddha, Banglar Christian, Banglar Musalman; Amra Sabai Bangali''.
The Liberation War was the inspiration for Kundu's most famous work, the sculpture ''[[Shabash Bangladesh]]'', a tribute to the fallen freedom fighters of the Mukti Bahini. This is situated on the campus of [[Rajshahi University]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Mirdha |first=Refayet Ullah |title=The 75,000 taka bed |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=24994 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref>
==Entrepreneur== In the 1975, following a brief stint at Bitopi advertising agency, Kundu established his own company, a furniture store featuring his own designs, [[Otobi]]. Within a relatively short period, Otobi became the most prominent Bangladeshi furniture brand. He started the company with an initial investment of 5000 taka.<ref name="Nitun Kundu: Our role model"/>
==Works== [[Image:Shabash Bangladesh.jpg|thumb|Shabash Bangladesh]] [[Image:Saarc Fowara.JPG|right|thumb|The [[SAARC]] fountain, Dhaka]] Kundu crafted several national trophies including National Film Award, President Gold Cup, [[Notun Kuri]] Award, Asia Cricket Cup, and the Ekushey Padak.<ref name=pass/>
His some notables works are the following: * Sada Jagrata Banglar Muktibahini (poster) * Amra Sabai Bangali (poster) * Banglar Bir Muktijoddha (poster) *[[Shabash Bangladesh]] (sculpture at [[University of Rajshahi]]) * [[SAARC Fountain]] at Karwan Bazar, Dhaka * Fountain, [[Dhaka High Court]], Dhaka * Sampan, [[Shah Amanat International Airport]], [[Chittagong]] * Kadam Fountain, [[National Press Club (Bangladesh)|National Press Club]], Dhaka
==Awards and honors== * [[Ekushey Padak]] (1997) * Daily Star-DHL Best Entrepreneur Award * National Film Award * President Gold Cup * Notun Kuri Award ([[Bangladesh Television]])
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Artists of Bangladesh}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kundu, Nitun}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:Bangladeshi sculptors]] [[Category:Bangladeshi painters]] [[Category:Recipients of the Ekushey Padak]] [[Category:Bangladeshi businesspeople]] [[Category:20th-century sculptors]] [[Category:20th-century Bangladeshi painters]]
