revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = Nova | logo = [[File:Nova (eikaiwa).svg]] | type = [[Private company|Private]] (owned by Jibun Mirai Associe Co. Ltd) | foundation = [[Osaka]], Japan (1981) | location = Osaka, Japan | industry = Language instruction | revenue = {{nowrap|{{loss}} 57,064 million [[Japanese Yen|JPY]] (2007){{cite web| url = http://www.jasdaq.co.jp/ir/show.do?lang=E&stock=JP3760300008| title = Consolidated Financials| accessdate =5 June 2007| year = 2007 | work = Jasdaq Interim and Consolidated Performance Figures| publisher = JASDAQ Securities}}}} | net_income = {{loss}} −2,495 million JPY (2007) | key_people = [[Nozomu Sahashi]] (founder, former CEO)
[[Masaki Inayoshi]] (former owner) | homepage = {{URL|http://www.nova.co.jp}} }} '''Nova''' (formerly '''Nova Group''') is a large [[eikaiwa school]] (private [[English (language)|English]] [[language education|teaching company]]) in Japan. It was by far the largest {{cite web |url=http://www.nova.ne.jp/english/corporation/05gaiyou/marketshare.html |title=Nova Market Share |accessdate=21 March 2007 |publisher=Japan Ministry of Economy via Nova Corp Website |date=2002–2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5aHdaYReV?url=http://www.nova.ne.jp/english/corporation/05gaiyou/marketshare.html |archivedate=23 August 2008 |df=dmy }} company of this type until its widely publicized collapse in October 2007. Before its [[bankruptcy]], Nova employed approximately 15,000 people across a group of companies that supported the operations of and extended out from the "Intercultural Network" of its language schools. The scope of its business operations reached its peak in February 2007 following a rapid expansion of its chain to 924 Nova branches plus a Multimedia Center located in [[Osaka]]. Nova, known for high-priced lesson packages, {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420857 |title=Stranded foreign teachers left penniless after Nova's fall |accessdate=31 October 2007 |publisher=[[Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry|METI]] |date=31 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5SzdzWNWF?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420857 |archivedate=31 October 2007 |df=dmy }} and later plagued by lawsuits and negative publicity, began to decline in earnest almost immediately after the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry placed a six-month ban against soliciting new long-term contracts from students on the company on 13 June 2007. {{cite web |url= http://www.meti.go.jp/press/20070613004/tokutei_press.pdf |format=PDF|title= METI Report on Nova |accessdate=29 September 2007 |publisher= METI |date= 13 June 2007 }} The impending financial crisis facing Nova related to a rapid increase in refund claims, significant drops in sales figures, and deterioration of its reputation, came to the fore in September 2007 when Nova began to delay payment of wages and [[Performance-related pay|bonuses]] to staff. The [[National Union of General Workers|NAMBU Foreign Workers Caucus]] in Tokyo estimated that up to 3,000 staff had not received their salaries on time. A solution for Nova's failure to pay wages was promised by 19 October in a fax sent to branch schools. On 23 October the Osaka Labor Standards office accepted a demand by [[Trade union|unionized]] Nova instructors to investigate criminal charges against Nova President and founder, [[Nozomu Sahashi]], over delayed and unpaid [[wage]]s, but Sahashi was ultimately not charged. It took roughly eight months for the company to reach the point where it filed for bankruptcy protection on 26 October 2007 whereupon the trading of its stock was suspended and was delisted on 27 November 2007. On 6 November 2007 court-appointed receivers announced that [[Nagoya]]-based [[G.Communication]] would sponsor Nova. Initial plans by G.com were to start with reopening up to 30 schools in various locations including Tokyo and Osaka by the end of November 2007. G.com later sold off its 490 Nova and 167 GEOS English schools on 1 October 2010 to Inayoshi Holdings, with 50 of the GEOS schools slated to join the Nova group under the name "Nova x Geos"Retooled English school chains set to launch Nova x Geos brand http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/business/T101014003658.htm Retrieved 16 October 2010 on 1 November 2010. As of 1 February 2012 Nova is owned by Jibun Mirai Associe Co. Ltd.{{cite web|title=Jibun Mirai website|url=http://www.jibunmirai.co.jp/|accessdate=6 June 2012}} On 2 September 2013 Jibun Mirai established a wholly owned subsidiary called Nova and fully reinstated the name Nova.Japan Times [http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/09/04/business/nova-reinstated-as-name-of-english-language-school-chain/ Nova reinstated as name of English-language school chain 4 September 2013] As of January 2014 Nova operates 310 branches,{{cite web|title=スクール検索|url=http://www.nova.co.jp/schools/|accessdate=2 January 2014}} with 66,000 students.Japan Times [http://www.japantimes.co.jp/community/2013/11/03/general/six-years-following-bankruptcy-nova-boosts-the-brand/ Six years following bankruptcy, Nova boosts the brand 3 November 2013] ==History== [[File:NOVA branch.JPG|thumb|A Nova branch]] The Nova Group was founded in August 1981 and was led by CEO [[Nozomu Sahashi]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.ekimae-nova.com/ |title=Nova Corporate profile |accessdate=21 March 2007 |publisher=nova.ne.jp |date=2002–2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071104082542/http://www.nova.ne.jp/english/corporation/05gaiyou/gaiyou.html |archivedate=4 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Nova's corporate headquarters were in Osaka. The company was the largest employer of foreign nationals in Japan, {{cite web |url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20050531zg.html |title= New Nova hours pose health risk |accessdate=4 June 2007 |publisher= The Japan Times |date= 31 May 2005 }} employing 7,000 foreign workers, 5,000 of whom were employed as language instructors. {{cite web |url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20050412zg.html |title= English schools face huge insurance probe |accessdate=20 March 2007 |publisher= The Japan Times |date=12 April 2005 }} Each year, Nova hired between 2,500 and 2,600 foreign teachers to replace those who had left. {{cite web |url= http://www.nova.ne.jp/ir/news/news070201.html |title= Notice from Nova regarding news reports |accessdate=29 March 2007 |publisher= Nova Web Site |date= 31 January 2007 }} Although instructors were not required to have actual educational training, the company provided a salary bonus for teachers with an accredited [[TEFL]] certificate, any master's degree, or a degree in education. Teachers were admitted directly after university graduation with any degree that allowed them to obtain a work visa. Instructors from participating countries {{cite web |url= http://www.mofa.go.jp/j_info/visit/w_holiday/index.html |title= Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan |accessdate=5 June 2007 |publisher= Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan}} who can obtain a [[Working Holiday Visa]] were admitted without a degree. They worked fewer hours and earned less pay than full-time instructors. Sahashi originally established the company with two high school graduates from Sweden and Canada whom he met via a friend who was studying abroad in Paris. They opened the first classroom in Shinsaibashi, Osaka. The name ''[[Nova]]'' (an astronomical term for a stellar explosion) was chosen by Sahashi as he felt it would appeal to prospective students. {{cite web |url=http://osaka.yomiuri.co.jp/eco_news/20070614ke03.htm |title=Nova – Restrictions Inevitable |accessdate=3 July 2007 |publisher=Yomiuri Shimbun |date=14 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Q48bIjXK?url=http://osaka.yomiuri.co.jp/eco_news/20070614ke03.htm |archivedate=3 July 2007 |df=dmy }} In November 1996, Nova's [[initial public offering]] was met with several demonstrations in front of [[Nomura Securities]] and the [[Tokyo Stock Exchange]]. A complaint filed by The [[National Union of General Workers|Nova Union]] stated that the company was violating Japanese exchange laws by falsely stating that there were no unions at Nova, nor pending litigation, and that labor relations between the company and its employees were amicable and untroubled.[http://www.novaunion.com/zet/UB8.html Media Critical of Nova in Wake of Public Stock Offering][http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M6.html "Union, management speak two tongues"] The Japan Times (31 January 1997)[http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M4.html "Nova is accused of lying in stock-listing prospectus"] The Japan Times, 19 December 1996 Since 1997, Nova steadily expanded the number of its schools as its business grew, going from 239 schools to 623 in 2004. By 2002, Nova had captured 50% of total market share by revenue (61.5 billion yen) and in 2003, Nova had gained a 66% market share by number of students, some 410,000 students in total. However 2005 saw Nova lose ground in total sales revenue. {{cite web |url=http://www.nova.ne.jp/ir/pdf/02market_share.pdf |title=Nova Corp. Website |accessdate=15 August 2007 |publisher=Nova |date= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R3qwhhXL?url=http://www.nova.ne.jp/ir/pdf/02market_share.pdf |archivedate=13 August 2007 |df=dmy }} The company was in the red in the business year ending in March for the second consecutive year, {{cite web |url = http://cc.msnscache.com/cache.aspx?q%3D8321206067110%26lang%3Dja-JP%26mkt%3Dja-JP%26FORM%3DCVRE6 |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/5R2Dh0oT3?url=http://cc.msnscache.com/cache.aspx?q=8321206067110&lang=ja-JP&mkt=ja-JP&FORM=CVRE6 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 12 August 2007 |title = Executives of scandal-tainted companies bow in remorse at shareholder meetings |accessdate = 12 August 2007 |publisher = Mainichi |date = 28 June 2007 |df = dmy-all }} posting net losses of 3 billion yen in fiscal 2005 and 2.4 billion yen in fiscal 2006 after a failed expansion attempt. The number of students fell to 418,000 by the end of March: down 12.1 percent from a year earlier. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706180093.html |title=Services: Nova Corp. eyes capital tie-up |accessdate=17 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=18 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R1kfNLUF?url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706180093.html |archivedate=12 August 2007 |df=dmy }} On 20 September 2007, NOVA announced it was considering a large-scale closure of up to 200 branches. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/life/update/0920/OSK200709200039.html |title=Nova considers closing 200 classrooms |accessdate=20 September 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=20 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5RzMGrqvI?url=http://www.asahi.com/life/update/0920/OSK200709200039.html |archivedate=20 September 2007 |df=dmy }} ===Events after the collapse=== The announcement of court protection and the admission that operations at all Nova branches would be temporarily shut down shocked the estimated 420,000 Nova students as some of them had paid their tuition in advance and feared their money might not be refunded. The [[Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry]] asked the [[Japan Association for the Promotion of Foreign Language Education]], an industry body, to call on its member schools to accept Nova students. METI also requested consumer credit companies not to seek loan repayments from the 20% of Nova students who paid their tuition with loans because Nova has ceased operations and they could not take lessons. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420669 |title=Gov't reluctant to get involved in bailing out Nova |accessdate=29 October 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=27 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Sx8l386b?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420669 |archivedate=29 October 2007 |df=dmy }} Nova President [[Nozomu Sahashi]], missing since before his dismissal, was officially replaced by three board members, including co-founder [[Anders Lundqvist]]. The Osaka Labor Bureau, a local branch of the [[Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (Japan)|Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare]], launched a consulting counter with five interpreters for foreign Nova instructors. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420582 |title=Nova granted court protection from creditors; president missing |accessdate=30 October 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=26 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5SyBTy4Zy?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420582 |archivedate=30 October 2007 |df=dmy }} The immediate effect of collapse of Nova was the sudden unemployment of approximately 4,500 foreign teaching staff and 2,000 Japanese workers. The desperate situation of many of the foreign teachers raised concerns over an apparent lack of an adequate safety net for foreign workers in Japan. Some teachers could not even afford a plane ticket home. {{cite web |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20071108/wl_asia_afp/japaneducationbankruptcycompanynova |title=English teachers feel abandoned after Japanese giant collapses |accessdate=9 November 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=7 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5TDMgfEKy?url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20071108/wl_asia_afp/japaneducationbankruptcycompanynova |archivedate=9 November 2007 |df=dmy }} The Australian and British embassies in Japan set up information pages on their websites to assist their nationals and Qantas airline offered reduced airfares for Australian Nova employees wishing to return to Australia. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420690 |title=Australian, British embassies assisting Nova instructors; Qantas offers cheaper fares home |accessdate=27 October 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=28 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5SuvlAHTA?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/420690 |archivedate=28 October 2007 |df=dmy }} The collapse led to huge increases in union membership, particularly in [[National Union of General Workers|NUGW Tokyo Nambu]] (future Tozen Union) and in Osaka's [[General Union]]. The unions had a chance to appeal their case to the public thanks to extensive coverage on TV, radio and newspaper. The unexpected influx of ex-Nova teachers on the job market led to immense numbers of applicants vying for a much smaller number of employment opportunities. Language education companies, even some outside Japan, attempted to tap into this labor force. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421212 |title=EF invites Nova instructors to teach in China for Olympics |accessdate=8 November 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=8 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5TLpA67V0?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421212 |archivedate=14 November 2007 |df=dmy }} The publicity, generated by the collapse in Japan and in other countries, also threatened to damage the reputation of Japan's foreign language industry although the Japanese government attempted to minimize the damage by pledging non-specific support despite remaining essentially uninvolved in the chaotic collapse. The government did set up a special consultation booth briefly at the [[Hello Work]] public employment office in Shinjuku in Tokyo for Nova instructors seeking advice but maintained its distance as its position was that the bankruptcy of Japan's biggest foreign language school chain was a private sector matter. Although Nova was unable to successfully attract a corporate partner to stave off the bankruptcy, twelve companies quickly applied for sponsorship to rebuild Nova Corp, some of which made specific proposals to turn around the company. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421036 |title=12 companies apply for sponsorship to rebuild Nova |accessdate=5 November 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=5 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5T8MnIRAj?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421036 |archivedate=5 November 2007 |df=dmy }} ===Restructuring=== On 7 November 2007, [[G.Communication]], a Nagoya-based operator of cram schools, language schools and restaurant chains announced it had been unofficially selected to take over part of the operations of failed Nova Corp before any official decision by the board of trustees had been released. G.Education Co, a subsidiary of G.communication, would take over part of Nova's operations in addition to the chain of [[EC Inc]] English conversation schools of Hokkaido it runs. Nova Corp assets not absorbed by G.communication would be liquidated by court appointed administrators. The administrators claimed they had to select a sponsor quickly even before the court approved Nova's reconstruction program as value of Nova corporate assets were eroding each day as employees and students left. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421159 |title=Nagoya-based G.communication to take over part of Nova operations |accessdate=6 November 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=7 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5TOGS8cwK?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421159 |archivedate=16 November 2007 |df=dmy }} Initial plans by G.communication were to start with reopening the Nova Kurokawa school in Nagoya's Kita Ward with the intention to reopen up to 30 schools in various locations including Tokyo & Osaka by the end of November 2007. G.communication held several briefing sessions for Nova employees and foreign teachers about their reemployment. Although many of the foreign teachers were not subsequently re-employed, G.communication has opened 465 schools as of January 2010. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421397 |title=G.communication to reopen 1st Nova school in Nagoya |accessdate=12 November 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=11 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5THfwcWpX?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/421397 |archivedate=12 November 2007 |df=dmy }} G.communication Co. sold off the Nova and Geos chains of English schools on 1 October 2010. An investment company led by Masaki Inayoshi, who formerly served as chairman of G.communication, purchased the subsidiary of the Nagoya-based firm that ran both GEOS and Nova.Geos, Nova English schools change ownership once again http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/business/T101005004522.htm Retrieved 16 October 2010 At the time of sale, Nova had 490 locations and Geos 167. Nova changed ownership again in 2012, being purchased by Jibun Mirai Associe Co. Ltd. However G.communication continues to operate some Nova schools through its subsidiaries G.networks and G.taste, under license from Jibun Mirai Associe. ==Branches as of 2012== As of May 2012 there are 212 Nova branches operating. 211 are located across Japan: nineteen in Hokkaido, nineteen in Kyushu, ten in Chugoku, six in Shikoku, thirty-six in Kansai, seventy-six in Kanto, and forty-five in Chubu; Nova has one branch located in Hawaii.{{cite web|title=ハワイ校|url=http://www.nova.co.jp/schools/1583.shtml|accessdate=23 May 2012}} ==Marketing and services== [[File:Nova-newinside-2008.jpg|thumb|The interior of a new Nova school showing the new design motifs]] Prior to its 2007 bankruptcy, the language school chain aggressively operated extensive advertising campaigns in print and on television and had a very high profile and strong [[brand recognition]]. {{cite web |url= http://archive.salon.com/people/feature/2000/06/29/japancelebs/ |title= How U.S. stars sell Japan to the Japanese |accessdate=30 June 2007 |publisher= Salon.com |date= 29 June 2000}} {{cite book | last = Philip Seargeant | first = Seargeant | title = "More English than England itself": the simulation of authenticity in foreign language practice in Japan | publisher = International Journal of Applied Linguistics | year = 2005 | pages = 326–345 | doi = 10.1111/j.1473-4192.2005.00094.x }} Until a short time before its collapse, Nova used an animated pink rabbit (the "Nova Usagi") as the popular face of the company, which appeared often as the focus of Nova's TV commercials and other advertisements. {{cite web |url= http://mdn.mainichi-msn.co.jp/waiwai/archive/news/2003/03/20030303p2g00m0dm999000c.html |title= Nova's abused bunny ad leaves activists hopping mad |accessdate=15 August 2007 |publisher= Mainichi |date= 3 March 2003}} The rabbit appealed strongly to children and became extremely popular. The introduction of "Nova Usagi" merchandise saw sales of over 260 million yen in the first two weeks of availability. {{cite web |url=http://www.jmintelligence.co.jp/trends/trends_2004_winter.html |title=Japan Market Research |accessdate=15 August 2007 |publisher=Japan Market Intelligence |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070430090958/http://www.jmintelligence.co.jp/trends/trends_2004_winter.html |archivedate=30 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Nova partially discontinued using the rabbit in January 2003 after [[JSPCA]] animal rights activists lodged a protest over a commercial that featured the rabbit getting its ears ripped off, citing concerns of its impact on children's awareness of death. Many Nova branches were (and still are) located near [[train station]]s, and the company used the term ''ekimae ryūgaku'' ("study abroad near the train station": 駅前留学) in its promotional materials. The catch phrase helped Nova to become the nation's biggest chain of English language schools.{{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706160079.html |title=Exploiting the zeal of Japanese to learn English |accessdate=1 July 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=16 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0QUoDwC?url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706160079.html |archivedate=1 July 2007 |df=dmy }} It similarly promoted its interactive multimedia network as ''ochanoma ryūgaku'' ("study abroad from the living room": お茶の間留学).{{cite web |url=http://www.nova.ne.jp/english/corporation/02jigyo/jigyou_ekicha.html |title=Nova Corp. Website |accessdate=15 August 2007 |publisher=Nova |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070610043100/http://www.nova.ne.jp/english/corporation/02jigyo/jigyou_ekicha.html |archivedate=10 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Nova's success was also attributed to its promises of a foreign teacher, smaller class sizes than its rivals, and an appointment system that allowed students to schedule and attend class at their convenience.{{cite web |url=http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M7.html |title=Nova students say they are learning how to watch their money disappear |accessdate=12 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun, reprinted with permission Nova Union website |date=1 February 1997 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R3BDpJGf?url=http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M7.html |archivedate=13 August 2007 |df=dmy }} However, in 1997, 18 students filed a [[grievance]] with the [[Tokyo Metropolitan Government]] claiming they were unable to make lesson appointments when they wanted, despite the school's advertisements that its students could reserve classes "at any time". The students said they had purchased hundreds of tickets when joining the school, but found it impossible to use them all by the expiry date due to inflexible scheduling procedures. Nova agreed to a proposal by the Damage Relief Committee to repay a total of 3.8 million yen and said the dispute had been the result of a misunderstanding.[http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M9.html "Nova to refund 3.8 million yen for students' unused lessons"] The Japan Times 13 June 1997. Reprinted with permission by Nova Union. Retrieved on 11 February 2007 ===Services=== The company offered English courses for adults, children, business English and test preparation ([[TOEFL]], [[TOEIC]]) as well as [[Chinese (language)|Chinese]], [[French (language)|French]], [[Spanish (language)|Spanish]], [[Italian (language)|Italian]], and [[German (language)|German]] instruction. Through subsidiaries, the company also offered [[telecommunications]] and [[travel agency]] services and in-house English instruction, [[translation]] and [[Language interpretation|interpretation]] services for Japanese corporations.{{cite web |url= http://www.glova.co.jp/ |title= Glova Website |accessdate=7 February 2007 |publisher= Glova |date= 6 June 2007 }} {{cite book | last = Graham | first = Jeffery |author2=Hideaki Miyajima |author3=Javed Maswood | title = Japan – Change and Continuity | publisher = Routledge | year = 2002 | isbn = 0-7007-1644-0 | page = 119 }} While Nova's main product was English language services, the company shifted some of its focus toward China, as 100,000 of its students studied Chinese.{{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706180116.html |title=Sizing up China: Language students put their money where their mouths are |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=16 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R1kcvjPI?url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706180116.html |archivedate=12 August 2007 |df=dmy }} ==Instructor employment system== * '''Full-time instructor'''Jibun Mirai Associe webpage [http://www.jibunmirai.co.jp/foreigner/working.html Working Conditions] Retrieved on 11 June 2012 ** Five day work week of eight 44-minute lessons per day. Duties may include cleaning or distributing tissues during free lessons ** 253,000 yen monthly salary which may vary depending on class capacity. Teachers are paid more for full or one on one classes, less for one or two student classes ** Transport allowance included in salary ** 10 paid holidays per year in the first 12-month contract. Different schools vary in whether they give public holidays or not. == Employment and labor relations == ===Drug testing=== In 1994, after two instructors were arrested on drug charges in August and September, Nova asked all 3,100 instructors to sign an agreement to have a mandatory drug test, the results of which would be reported to the police. The drug test only applied to foreign staff.{{cite web |url=http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M2.html |title=Nova teachers seeking legal help |accessdate=11 February 2007 |publisher=The Japan Times, Reprinted with permission by Nova Union |date=1 October 1994 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070727185208/http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M2.html |archivedate=27 July 2007 |df=dmy }} [http://www.novaunion.com/zet/M3.html "Nova teachers pan drug test: staffers urge school to end 'illegal labor practices'"] The Japan Times 1994 Reprinted with permission by Nova Union. Retrieved on 11 February 2007 The Osaka Bar Association wrote an opinion that the policy was a violation of the teachers' right to privacy.[http://www.generalunion.org/nova/drugruling.htm Letter of Recommendation] Osaka Bar Association. Retrieved on 20 March 2007 Nova claimed consent forms had been received from more than 90 percent of employees. According to the union, no instructors were ever required to take a drug test.[http://www.novaunion.com/zet/accomplishments.html "Our Accomplishments"] Nova Union of Teachers. Retrieved on 11 February 2007 ===Shakai hoken=== In March 2005, after NUGW Tokyo Nambu and the [[National Union of General Workers|General Union]] filed a complaint, Nova and other English schools in Japan were investigated by the [[Social Insurance Agency]] for not enrolling employees in {{nihongo |Social Insurance|[[:ja:社会保険|社会保険]],| Shakai Hoken }}. The law stipulates that companies with full-time workers who have been in Japan for more than two months must enroll them in the system. Payment is split between employer and employee, each paying about half the monthly premium amount.{{cite web |url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/member/member.html?appURL=fl20050412zg.html |title= English schools face huge insurance probe |accessdate=20 March 2007 |publisher= The Japan Times |date= 12 April 2005 }} In June 2005, Nova amended its working times for instructors and standardized lesson length to 40 minutes, with two minutes either side for lesson planning and student evaluation, resulting in a total lesson time of 44 minutes. Six to eleven minutes of unpaid time was left between classes. As a result of changes to working hours, regular non-titled teachers whose work weeks were reduced to slightly under 30 hours became ineligible for ''shakai hoken'', giving an estimated savings to the company of over one billion yen in annual premium payments. Such employees can register for [[National Health Insurance (Japan)|National Health Insurance]] (a different system to Shakai Hoken), although this system does not offer coverage for time taken off work due to illness. Nova also offered its own private insurance program. === Anti-fraternization policy === After six employees were fired for violating a clause in their contracts that forbade interaction between students and instructors outside the classroom, a complaint was filed with the [[Attorney at law (Japan)|Osaka Bar Association]] by two employees who were members of the General Union, one of whom had been dismissed as a result of the policy. The two instructors claimed the policy violated their human rights and argued it was racial discrimination since it only applied to foreigners. The clause in Nova's labor contract stated that foreign teachers "should not have a relationship with customers outside the workplace."[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/member/member.html?nn20030301b8.htm Nova's ban on dating violates rights: teachers] The Japan Times (1 March 2003) retrieved 1 July 2007 The Osaka Bar Association subsequently issued a non-binding recommendation that the company drop the clause, saying that it restricted instructors' freedom of association and discriminated between foreign and Japanese staff.[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20040226b4.html Nova, let teachers date students: bar] The Japan Times (26 February 2004). Retrieved on 1 July 2007 The company said the clause was there to "protect both the teachers and the students from trouble, as they do not know each other's cultures and customs."[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20040601zg.html No sex please, you're teachers: Nova teachers unhappy with rules, reports] The Japan Times (1 June 2004). Retrieved on 22 March 2007 On 11 December 2005, an Australian who had been teaching in an Osaka Nova branch reached an out-of-court settlement of ¥400,000[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/member/nn20051211a2.html Nova to pay teacher over demotion] The Japan Times(11 December 2005). Retrieved on 1 July 2007 and a letter of commendation after claiming that the policy had interfered with his life. The then 30-year-old teacher had been demoted and transferred to another school branch in 2004 when Nova found out he had a relationship with a 21-year-old student. {{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/hard-lessons-from-teaching-english-in-japan/2006/03/14/1142098460885.html?page=fullpage |title= Hard lessons in broken English |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher= Sydney Morning Herald |date= 15 March 2006}} === Contested dismissals === In November 2004, union supporters gathered outside Nova's Shinjuku Honko school, protesting dismissals of five teachers, three of whom had been working at Nova for more than 10 years. All were members of the Nova union (a branch of the [[National Union of General Workers|NUGW]]). The union alleged they were dismissed due to their union activities. {{cite web |url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20041123zg.html |title= Class Action |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher= Japan Times |date= 23 November 2004}} In March 2006, Kara Harris reached a financial settlement with Nova for approximately 7 million yen after she had been dismissed following her request to be made a permanent employee during negotiations with Nova over her sixth consecutive contract. {{cite web |url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20060328zg.html |title= Times get tough for teachers |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher= Japan Times |date= 28 March 2006}} Nova had originally offered her a 12-month extension and, after disputes with her manager over several issues, she sued Nova for wrongful dismissal. Successive courts found that Harris was unfairly treated by Nova. ===Unions=== Throughout Japan staff at Nova are represented by various unions. In Kyushu some staff belong to the Fukuoka General union,Fukuoka General Union website [http://fukuoka.generalunion.org/news/nova_september2007.html Nova issues] Retrieved on 1 June 2012 in Kansai some instructors belong to the [[General Union]].General Union website [http://www.generalunion.org/nova/] Retrieved on 1 June 2012 Both of these unions belong to the [[National Union of General Workers]], which is itself a member of the confederation [[Zenrokyo]] (National Trade Union Council).General Union website [http://www.generalunion.org/affiliation General Union Affiliation] Retrieved on 1 June 2012 ==Government intervention== ===Concerns about refund policy=== On 14 February 2007, the Ministry of Trade, Economy and Industry and the Tokyo Metropolitan Government conducted on-the-spot inspections at Nova Headquarters in Osaka and several other branches. {{cite web |url=http://www.zakzak.co.jp/top/2007_02/t2007021624.html |title=Inspection over frequent cancellation problems at Nova |accessdate=13 August 2007 |publisher=ZakZak |date=16 February 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5QpOc1QS0?url=http://www.zakzak.co.jp/top/2007_02/t2007021624.html |archivedate=3 August 2007 |df=dmy }} Officials said that several Nova schools failed to give full refunds to students who canceled their remaining lessons after paying in advance. Other clients said that Nova refused to accept unconditional cancellation of lessons, claiming the eight-day "cooling-off" period had expired, and had also deceived students by giving false information about their cancellation procedures.[https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0Ll32vD?url=http://cc.msnscache.com/cache.aspx?q=8247506639759&lang=ja-JP&mkt=ja-JP&FORM=CVRE3 "Nova raided after complaints over missing tuition fees"] Mainichi Daily News 16 February 2007. Retrieved on 21 February 2007[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nb20070217a1.html "Nova probed over refunds, deception"] The Japan Times 17 February 2007. Retrieved on 21 February 2007[http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200702170164.html "Nova searched in contract row"] The Asahi Shimbun 17 February 2007. Retrieved on 21 February 2007 The Kyoto Consumers Contract Network NPO also expressed similar concerns.[http://mdn.mainichi-msn.co.jp/waiwai/archive/news/2007/02/20070227p2g00m0dm005000c.html "Students at 'McEnglish' schools taste the spit in the burger"] Weekly Playboy 21 March 2007. Retrieved on 5 June 2007 Reductions in the number of teaching staff since 2004 had created a situation where students found it increasingly difficult to schedule classes, precipitating a substantial increase in complaints. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/special/070614/TKY200706160162.html |title=Nova President "No need to stop selling because of insufficient teachers" |accessdate=16 June 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=16 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R9TVFgac?url=http://www.asahi.com/special/070614/TKY200706160162.html |archivedate=17 August 2007 |df=dmy }} During the February office inspections the Ministry discovered a memo in which Sahashi stated there was no need to stop pushing sales despite difficulties meeting student reservations due to teacher shortages. {{cite web |url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/20070615TDY03002.htm |title=Students, ex-staff critical of Nova |accessdate=1 July 2007 |publisher=Yomiuri Shimbun |date=15 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0K76Dsd?url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/20070615TDY03002.htm |archivedate=1 July 2007 |df=dmy }} Consumer centers nationwide received more than 1,000 complaints and queries regarding Nova annually and the National Consumer Affairs Center of Japan says it received some 7,600 complaints or inquiries about Nova's contract and cancellation policies between 1996 and March 2007. {{cite web |url = http://cc.msnscache.com/cache.aspx?q%3D8293749833684%26lang%3Dja-JP%26mkt%3Dja-JP%26FORM%3DCVRE4 |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/5R2DMznAI?url=http://cc.msnscache.com/cache.aspx?q=8293749833684&lang=ja-JP&mkt=ja-JP&FORM=CVRE4 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 12 August 2007 |title = Nova ordered to repay English tuition fees to man who cancelled contract |accessdate = 12 August 2007 |publisher = Mainichi Shimbun |date = 3 April 2007 |df = dmy-all }} Under Nova's system, students bought points in advance to pay for their lessons. The larger number of points they bought, the smaller the individual class fee became. The case taken to the top court involved a former student who had purchased 600 points at a rate of 1,200 yen per lesson. The student canceled the contract after using 386 points, Nova offered a refund based on a calculation that 300 points were bought, resulting in a price of 1,750 yen per lesson.[http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706120415.html LDP lawmaker vouched for Nova] The Asahi Shimbun 13 June 2007. Retrieved on 13 June 2007 Nova said the value of the used points should be calculated as having been bought in smaller lots.[http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706130249.html Ministry to order Nova to halt part of its operations] The Asahi Shimbun 13 June 2007. Retrieved on 1 June 2007 The ''Asahi Shimbun'' cites an example of a contract for 100 lessons, which would cost 230,000 yen in advance, for a per-lesson fee of 2,300 yen. A contract for 600 lessons would require an advance payment of 720,000 yen, or 1,200 yen per class. But if a person with a contract for 600 lessons canceled after taking only 100 classes, Nova would apply the fee of 2,300 yen per lesson, and the student would receive a refund of 490,000 yen. Such students say the contract for 1,200 yen per lesson should have applied in these cases, which would result in a refund of 600,000 yen. ===Supreme Court appeal rejected=== On 4 April 2007, Nova's appeal on two lower court rulings was rejected by the [[Supreme Court of Japan|Supreme Court]] which described Nova's refund policy as invalid and in violation of specified commercial transaction law.[http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200704040097.html "Top court: Nova's refund tactic illegal"] The Asahi Shimbun 4 April 2007. Retrieved on 7 June 2007[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20070404a1.html "Nova's policy on cancellations illegal: top court"] The Japan Times 4 April 2007. Retrieved 7 June 2007 The ruling prompted the Ministry of Trade, Economy and Industry to revise the regulations for the specified commercial transaction law to prevent a recurrence of trouble. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200704140086.html |title=Ministry to clear up rules on refunds |accessdate=16 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=14 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R1kXOQdZ?url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200704140086.html |archivedate=12 August 2007 |df=dmy }} On 13 June 2007, LDP Lower House member [[Yasuhide Nakayama]] acknowledged he was accompanied by Sahashi and vouched for the company during a meeting with Osaka Mayor Junichi Seki on the morning of 22 May 2006, during the court dispute over the company's refund system. Nakayama, who was elected from an Osaka constituency (of which Sahashi was a member of the lawmaker's support organization) recalled saying at the time that it was "not right by social norms that Nova's refund rule is unacceptable" and explained "it is a politician's job to help out when a supporter is in trouble." Nakayama stated it was not his intention to exert pressure and Mayor Seki said he did not think the judgment of city officials was swayed by the lawmaker's visit. Industry minister [[Akira Amari]] also admitted on 22 June 2007 that he met with Yasuhide Nakayama earlier that year in February shortly after his ministry began investigating the school. Nakayama sought a meeting with Amari to express concern that the ministry might discipline the school over its fee discount system. Amari stated that Nakayama did not try to sway him from punitive action. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706230091.html |title=Tokyo: Amari admits visit over Nova inquiry |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=23 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0QAA0X5?url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706230091.html |archivedate=1 July 2007 |df=dmy }} ===Business restrictions imposed=== On 13 June 2007, the [[Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry]] imposed a six-month ban on Nova from soliciting, accepting or finalizing new contracts for long-term courses that last for over a year or 70 hours. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706130423.html |title=Rule-breaking Nova hit with suspension order |accessdate=1 July 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=14 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0NIHpaC?url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200706130423.html |archivedate=1 July 2007 |df=dmy }} {{cite web |url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/20070614TDY01002.htm |title=Nova barred from making long contracts |accessdate=1 July 2007 |publisher=Yomiuri Shimbun |date=14 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0QyqQnk?url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/20070614TDY01002.htm |archivedate=1 July 2007 |df=dmy }} The ban was imposed because of issues regarding refunds for the cancellation of contracts. {{cite web |url=http://mdn.mainichi-msn.co.jp/national/news/20070613p2a00m0na015000c.html |title=Nova handed suspension order over tuition fee practices |accessdate=13 June 2007 |publisher=Mainichi Daily News |date=13 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0PNq3nu?url=http://mdn.mainichi-msn.co.jp/national/news/20070613p2a00m0na015000c.html |archivedate=1 July 2007 |df=dmy }} The six months suspension order did not affect those who had already signed up for lessons, meaning that Nova's students were able to continue taking classes. The ministry also said that Nova failed to comply with a "cooling-off" system provided for in the specified commercial transaction law. Under this system, consumers can cancel a contract without conditions if the cancellation is made within eight days from when the contract was signed. At Nova, potential students first registered their name, address and other data before finalizing their contracts. An official application to the school was made several days later, after the details of the contract are decided upon. Nova told students who wanted to quit that they could not use the cooling-off system, claiming that the day students registered their data was the first day of the contract. On 15 June 2007, the [[Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (Japan)|Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare]] said that Nova's English language courses would no longer qualify for government subsidies for those engaged in educational training authorized by the welfare ministry to improve the abilities of the unemployed and other people. In 1999, Nova's 32 courses were approved for the subsidies program. In fiscal 2006, about 4,700 people received a total of 560 million yen in subsidies under the program. Since 1999, around 71,000 Nova students received a total of about 16.1 billion yen in such subsidies.[https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0Q2xKsk?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/409644 Nova eyes new share issuance to dispel market concerns after gov't terminates subsidies] Kyodo News via Japan Today (16 June 2007) Retrieved on 16 June 2007. Nova submitted a business improvement plan to the Tokyo government in late June 2007 as required by the [[Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry|METI]] conditions. Originally instructed to submit the plan on 10 June, Nova postponed the submission until 24 June. {{cite web |url=http://news.www.infoseek.co.jp/search/story/11mainichiF20070811p1500m020007/NOVA/ |title=Nova postpones performance report |accessdate=13 August 2007 |publisher=Mainichi News |date=4 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R3xllPE4?url=http://news.www.infoseek.co.jp/search/story/11mainichiF20070811p1500m020007/NOVA/ |archivedate=13 August 2007 |df=dmy }} The plan was rejected on the basis that it was lacking in concrete details and the planned improvement measures were deemed "insufficient". Nova was requested to submit an additional report. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/special/070614/TKY200706270397.html |title=Nova Improvement plan lacks details |accessdate=16 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=13 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5R9RdTp5k?url=http://www.asahi.com/special/070614/TKY200706270397.html |archivedate=17 August 2007 |df=dmy }} ===Events following restrictions=== In an interview in ''[[The Daily Yomiuri]]'' on 16 June 2007, Sahashi said he was considering offers of capital and business alliances from several companies in various industries, including retail firms, to deal with an expected drop in sales and to restore trust in the company and possibly selling off properties and real estate in Osaka estimated to be worth several billion yen.[https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0Q60A0Y?url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/business/20070616TDY01003.htm Nova boss weighs assistance options] The Daily Yomiuri (16 June 2007). Retrieved on 16 June 2007. A capital alliance would have served to improve its creditworthiness and secure operating expenses. In July 2007, Sahashi met with [[Hideo Sawada]], chairman of [[H.I.S. (travel agency)|H.I.S. travel agency]], to discuss a financial assistance as well as a business tie-up[http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200707030119.html Travel agency H.I.S. eyes alliance with struggling Nova] The Asahi Shimbun (3 July 2007). Retrieved on 9 July 2007 but the meeting did not conclude with a decision.[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nb20070703a2.html H.I.S. may come to Nova's aid] The Japan Times (3 July 2007) Retrieved 9 July 2007 {{cite web |url=http://asia.news.yahoo.com/070702/kyodo/d8q48ako0.html |title=H.I.S. mulls assisting scandal-hit Nova's turnaround efforts |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher=Kyodo News |date=6 July 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Q5LyNWuY?url=http://asia.news.yahoo.com/070702/kyodo/d8q48ako0.html |archivedate=4 July 2007 |df=dmy }} Although Sahashi had rejected the possibility of a business affiliation with another English school, [[Benesse|Benesse Corporation]] (parent company of [[Berlitz Language Schools]] and provider of home nursing services) announced that it would not be undertaking any business relationship with Nova[http://www.nikkansports.com/general/f-gn-tp0-20070712-226041.html Benesse considers support for Nova] Nikkan Sports (12 July 2007) Retrieved 12 August 2007 and saw no synergy between the two companies.[http://www.nikkei.co.jp/news/sangyo/20070712AT1D1206M12072007.html Benesse Chairman: No synergy with Nova] Nikkei Business Daily (12 July 2007). Retrieved on 12 August 2007 Sahashi indicated the company might have issued new shares to strengthen its capital and that Nova management "[would have to] take responsibility," stating the company would set up an internal inquiry and management reform committee to investigate the scandal, consider disciplinary measures of its executives (including himself), and examine how best to avoid scandals in the future. {{cite web |url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/410876 |title=Nova president refuses to resign |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher=JASDAQ |date=29 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0KC8sH4?url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/410876 |archivedate=1 July 2007 |df=dmy }} Sahashi also said that the company would not need assistance from financial organizations During its annual stockholder meeting in June, he apologized for causing the disciplinary action by the government and told the shareholders, "We'd like to regain your trust as soon as possible". Forty-six shareholders attended, and one shareholder who had apparently lost faith in the current Nova management called on them to resign.[https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0QubXdp?url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/20070629TDY02007.htm Shareholders meetings reach peak / Nova, Katokichi, Kajima among scandal-hit firms grilled by investors] The Yomiuri Shimbun (29 June 2007) Retrieved 12 August 2007 In response to this call, Sahashi refused stating "If I resign, the company will collapse,". On 14 August 2007 Nova announced and subsequently sold 170,000 new shares on 30 August. {{cite web |url= https://www.release.tdnet.info/inbs/380e0610_20070814.pdf |format=PDF|title= Stock Issue Announcement |accessdate=21 August 2007 |publisher= JASDAQ |date= 14 August 2007}} ==2007 financial crisis== Indications of an impending financial crisis stemmed from a rapid increase in refund claims that total nearly 5,000,000,000 yen nationwide. A 21 August 2007, article in the ''[[Toyo Keizai]]'', Nova was described as repeatedly delaying payment to business partners and banks, falling into arrears for printing costs at the end of July, asking an ad agency to defer a payment. {{cite web |url = http://www.toyokeizai.net/online/tk/headline/detail.php?kiji_no%3D209%26page%3D |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/5RFuxu6RU?url=http://www.toyokeizai.net/online/tk/headline/detail.php?kiji_no=209&page= |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 21 August 2007 |title = The end of the road for Nova's business practices as cash flow crunch intensifies |accessdate = 21 August 2007 |publisher = Toyo Keizai (Toyo Economics) |date = 21 August 2007 |df = dmy-all }} Nova's 2007 first quarter financials showed a loss of 4,300,000,000 yen, a 19% decrease in sales compared to the previous year period, and an overall 19% decrease in recurring profit. Nova cited the decrease in the number of students and deterioration of its image as an explanation. {{cite web |url = http://company.nikkei.co.jp/news/news.cfm?Nik_Code%3D0030030%26Page%3D1%26Back_sid%3DIR_CT%26KIJIID%3D20070827NSS0163%26DATE_FORSEARCH%3D2007/08/27 |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/5RTN7kZzd?url=http://company.nikkei.co.jp/news/news.cfm?Nik_Code=0030030&Page=1&Back_sid=IR_CT&KIJIID=20070827NSS0163&DATE_FORSEARCH=2007%2F08%2F27 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 30 August 2007 |title = Nova sees decrease in students and 4,300,000,000 yen loss in Q1. |accessdate = 30 August 2007 |publisher = Nikkei Market News |date = 27 August 2007 |df = dmy-all }} {{cite web |url = http://company.nikkei.co.jp/news/news.cfm?Nik_Code%3D0030030%26Page%3D1%26Back_sid%3DIR_CT%26KIJIID%3D20070825NKM0229%26DATE_FORSEARCH%3D2007/08/25 |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/5RTN9ht22?url=http://company.nikkei.co.jp/news/news.cfm?Nik_Code=0030030&Page=1&Back_sid=IR_CT&KIJIID=20070825NKM0229&DATE_FORSEARCH=2007%2F08%2F25 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 30 August 2007 |title = Nova down 4,300,000,000 yen loss in Q1, sees decrease in student enrollment. |accessdate = 30 August 2007 |publisher = Nikkei Market News |date = 25 August 2007 |df = dmy-all }} The ''[[Asahi Shimbun]]'' reported on 11 September 2007, that Nova had made a request to an asset management consulting company, requiring them to return an outstanding amount of 8 million shares that were loaned to them on 30 July 2007. Nova had previously used the asset management consulting company to arrange short term financing with an 11 million share stock loan on 29 July 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/business/update/0911/OSK200709110068.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070911143429/http://www.asahi.com/business/update/0911/OSK200709110068.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 September 2007 |title=Nova requests consulting company return 8,000,000 stocks |accessdate=11 September 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=11 September 2007 }} [[BNP Paribas]] had obtained the 8 million shares from a third party on 30 July selling them on 4 September. {{cite web |url = http://www.jiji.com/jc/c?g%3Dind_30%26k%3D2007090400993 |archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/5ReLp9PY4?url=http://www.jiji.com/jc/c?g=ind_30&k=2007090400993 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 6 September 2007 |title = BNP Parabas sells stock, has 0% stake in Nova |accessdate = 6 September 2007 |publisher = Jiji Press |date = 4 September 2007 |df = dmy-all }} Commenting on its temporary possession of Nova shares, BNP said it had been the result of the asset management consulting company exercising its option. {{cite web |url= http://www.sankei.co.jp/keizai/shijo/070912/shj070912000.htm |title= Nova requests consulting company to return 8,000,000 shares |accessdate=12 September 2007 |publisher= Sankei Shimbun |date= 12 September 2007}} ===Unpaid/Delayed wages=== A decline in the stock price following the release of Nova's 2008 fiscal year first quarter financials {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/business/toyo/kabuto/TKZ200708270009.html |title=Nova shares fall after poor performance in 1st quarter |accessdate=29 August 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shimbun |date=27 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5RRkoQQfX?url=http://www.asahi.com/business/toyo/kabuto/TKZ200708270009.html |archivedate=29 August 2007 |df=dmy }} was preceded by news of a delay in payment of wages and bonuses to some employees. {{cite web |url = http://headlines.yahoo.co.jp/hl?a=20070802-00000929-san-soci |title = Nova explains a 'system trouble' causing delays of wages |accessdate = 16 August 2007 |publisher = Sutra newspapers via Yahoo Japan |date = 2 August 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5R8eLKUbY?url=http://headlines.yahoo.co.jp/hl?a=20070802-00000929-san-soci |archivedate = 16 August 2007 |df = dmy-all }} Nova explained that the delay in the monthly wages was due to change in its payment system and personnel management and accounting sections that had not been completed on time and that the summer bonus delay until October was a business necessity that required employee co-operation. {{cite web |url= http://www.iza.ne.jp/news/newsarticle/business/72640/ |title= Unpaid salary showing a predicament for Nova management? |accessdate=16 August 2007 |publisher= Iza News |date= 1 August 2007}} On 14 September 2007, Nova delayed wages to many of its teaching staff. Many teachers who had previously resigned never received salary payments from the month of July. {{cite web |url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20071017a2.html |title= Unions want Nova, president indicted over payroll delays |accessdate= |publisher= Japan Times |date= 17 October 2007}} The [[National Union of General Workers|NAMBU Foreign Workers Caucus]] in Tokyo estimated that up to 3,000 had not received their salaries on time. According to the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'', some teachers said they were owed "thousands of dollars" and others posted messages expressing the intent to quit. Sahashi issued a statement saying it had not been possible to complete all the necessary operations to deposit instructor salaries. {{cite web |url= http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/teachers-unpaid-as-company-falters/2007/09/18/1189881511712.html |title= Teachers unpaid as company falters |accessdate=19 September 2007 |publisher= Sydney Morning Herald |date= 19 September 2007}} As a result of Nova delaying the payment of salaries, the ''[[Sankei Shimbun]]'' reported that insecurity spread amongst both staff and students surrounding the possible closures of Nova branches. On 20 September one teacher who demonstrated outside of Nova's office in Osaka was quoted as saying "I've already heard about the possible closures of 200 to 300 branches across the country. Nova no longer has the ability to pay the salaries of teachers and staff." {{cite web |url= http://www.sankei.co.jp/shakai/jiken/070920/jkn070920029.htm |title= Nova closures spread insecurity among staff and students |accessdate=20 September 2007 |publisher= Sankei Shimbun |date= 20 September 2007}} By 25 September the cash flow problems had not improved and Sahashi mortgaged 9 million shares of company stock (which included 1.18 million of his own personal shares) for the purposes of raising working capital. Nova Corporation said that they were not involved in planning the transaction. {{cite web |url=http://www.sponichi.co.jp/society/flash/KFullFlash20070925059.html |title=Nova financing via 9 million share mortgage? |accessdate=25 September 2007 |publisher=Sponichi Annex News |date=25 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5S7MZYjid?url=http://www.sponichi.co.jp/society/flash/KFullFlash20070925059.html |archivedate=25 September 2007 |df=dmy }} A fax sent to branches after 9 pm on Friday 12 October informed all instructors that salaries would not be met on 15 October as scheduled. {{cite web |url= http://www.japanprobe.com/?p=2926 |title= No Pay For Nova Teachers on October 15th |accessdate=16 October 2007 |publisher= Japan Probe |date= 14 October 2007}} The fax promised a solution for 19 October, the day Nova was required to submit its new business plan to JASDAQ after its previous plan was rejected by the Securities Exchange on 5 October for being insufficient.{{cite web|url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/national/news/20071006p2a00m0na034000c.html |title=Jasdaq rejects NOVA report on improvement measures |accessdate=16 October 2007 |publisher=Mainichi Daily News |date=24 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010123111/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/national/news/20071006p2a00m0na034000c.html |archivedate=10 October 2007 }} When salaries were not disbursed on 15 October, union representatives from both Tokyo based NAMBU Foreign Workers Caucus and the Osaka-based General Union approached the Labor Standards Inspection Office to file a report and request an inquest in unpaid wages. The Unions estimated that about 4,000 foreign teachers to salary went unpaid of which about 2,000 employees were still awaiting wages from the previous month that had been delayed since 27 September. The Unions also filed complaints reporting that Nova had withheld member's rent payment and the landlords had tried ask teachers to leave repeatedly. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/life/update/1016/TKY200710160415.html |title=NOVA unions consider effect of bankruptcy |accessdate=16 October 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shinbun |date=17 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Sfp027i6?url=http://www.asahi.com/life/update/1016/TKY200710160415.html |archivedate=18 October 2007 |df=dmy }} By 20 October there had been both union organized and wildcat strikes over the unpaid wages. The numerous delays of wages also led individual teachers also to boycott classes. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/kansai/news/OSK200710220013.html |title=Foreign teachers striking at Nova |accessdate=21 October 2007 |publisher=Asahi Shinbun |date=22 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5SlooO6W9?url=http://www.asahi.com/kansai/news/OSK200710220013.html |archivedate=22 October 2007 |df=dmy }} On 23 October, the Osaka Labor Standards office accepted a demand by Nova instructors to investigate criminal charges against Sahashi over delayed and unpaid wages.{{cite web|url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/national/news/20071023p2a00m0na003000c.html |title=Labor standards office questions Nova staff |accessdate=24 October 2007 |publisher=Mainichi Daily News |date=24 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023182348/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/national/news/20071023p2a00m0na003000c.html |archivedate=23 October 2007 }} One example of the employment fallout after the collapse was the experience of small private school in Higashinari Ward of Osaka, which said 400 people applied in October for a single job opening. The collapse caught some former teachers in such dire financial straits that they had to rely on their former students to feed them. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200711080113.html |title=Cover Story: Nova fallout |accessdate=8 November 2007 |publisher=Mainichi Daily News |date=8 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5TOnKUHwI?url=http://www.asahi.com/english/Herald-asahi/TKY200711080113.html |archivedate=16 November 2007 |df=dmy }} ===Sahashi's removal=== On 26 October 2007, Nova's stock was delisted and all branches closed, following an emergency board meeting that removed Sahashi from his position as head of the company.{{cite web |url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20071026z1.html |title= NOVA files for Bankruptcy Protection |accessdate=27 October 2007 |publisher= The Japan Times |date= 26 October 2007}} In June 2008, after a volunteer questioning with Osaka Prefectural Police, a warrant was served and Sahashi was arrested on charges of [[embezzlement]]. Sahashi denied charges of wrongdoing and insisted that the 320 million yen reserve fund personally created through a firm affiliated with Nova effectively under Sahashi's control had been set up to refund tuition fees to students who had canceled their lessons.{{cite news | title = Former Nova chief arrested – Sahashi grilled over misuse of ¥320 million in worker benefits | publisher = The Japan Times| date = 25 June 2008| url = http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20080625a1.html | accessdate =30 July 2008}} === Nonpayment of employee housing rent === Foreign staff risked losing company-sponsored housing after Nova stopped paying their rent, which they did well before the official announcements of impending bankruptcy. Paul Dorey, an official of the General Union, said: "Some teachers have already received eviction notices. It’s a total mess."{{cite news | last= Soble | first= Jonathan | url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/92cd2da8-85b1-11dc-8170-0000779fd2ac.html | title= Nova hits Japan’s English lessons | publisher= [[Financial Times]] | date= 29 October 2007 | accessdate=29 October 2007 }} ==Lawsuits== The parents of a Nova employee who committed [[suicide]] in 2004 filed a suit against the company on 31 August 2007. Their son, age 28 at the time, was employed by Nova to design and supervise the construction of new classrooms. During that period Nova was engaged in a rapid expansion meant to increase the number of Nova branches by 300 in an attempt to reach a total of 1,000. The parents' suit alleges that their son was required by Nova to work up to 80 hours of overtime in one month, and even through the night on seven occasions, despite his inexperience. At one point he had requested to be relieved but was persuaded to stay, which eventually led to overwhelming stress shortly before his suicide. {{cite web |url = http://headlines.yahoo.co.jp/hl?a=20070901-00000126-mailo-l13 |title = Parents seek recognition for their son's suicide |accessdate = 1 September 2007 |publisher = Mainichi Daily News |date = 1 September 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5Razi0LgY?url=http://headlines.yahoo.co.jp/hl?a=20070901-00000126-mailo-l13 |archivedate = 4 September 2007 |df = dmy-all }} On 3 September 2007, an Osaka woman filed suit against Nova over a refund related issue. Unlike previous complaints about how Nova adjusted the value of unused lesson points on which the Supreme Court ruled in June 2007, this suit contested Nova's decision not to refund lesson points that were extended after the woman purchased additional points. {{cite web |url = http://headlines.yahoo.co.jp/hl?a=20070903-00000215-yom-soci |title = Woman files suit against Nova seeking carryover point refund |accessdate = 4 September 2007 |publisher = [[Yomiuri Shimbun]] via Yahoo News |date = 3 September 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5RazZIhKE?url=http://headlines.yahoo.co.jp/hl?a=20070903-00000215-yom-soci |archivedate = 4 September 2007 |df = dmy-all }} The woman claims that while Nova explained that her unused points (worth approximately 400,000 yen) from the first contract would carry over after signing a new contract, she was not told that they could not be refunded if she chose to cancel. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/national/update/0903/TKY200709030320.html |title=Woman Takao, sues Nova for an 'unjustly low' refund |accessdate=3 September 2007 |publisher=[[Asahi Shimbun]] |date=3 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5RZoz2PDM?url=http://www.asahi.com/national/update/0903/TKY200709030320.html |archivedate=3 September 2007 |df=dmy }} In October 2008, approximately a year after the collapse, 24 former students filed a class action lawsuit against accounting firms KPMG AZSA & Co, former Nova president Sahashi, and five of the directors of the company claiming that the rapid expansion was pursued in a reckless manner, and that upfront lesson fees were being misappropriated. {{cite web |url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20081018b1.html |title=Students sue Nova to get tuition back |accessdate=18 October 2008 |publisher=[[Japan Times]] |date=17 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5bfaUCJAq?url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20081018b1.html |archivedate=18 October 2008 |df=dmy }} The suit further claims that Sahashi and his directors were negligent in their duties to fulfill obligations to customers. It also accuses five directors and two accounting firms of participating in the bankruptcy of Nova by allowing it to continue to use illicit accounting practices. Those accused allegedly inflated profit reports by recording 45% of the paid-in-advance tuition fees as part of its sales. The suit seeks a total of 16 million yen in compensation. {{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/kansai/news/OSK200810170008.html |title=24 former Nova students seek 16 million yen in compensation in class action suit |accessdate=18 October 2008 |publisher=[[Asahi Shimbun]] |date=17 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5bfaeJZkh?url=http://www.asahi.com/kansai/news/OSK200810170008.html |archivedate=18 October 2008 |df=dmy }} {{cite web |url = http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/national/news/20081017p2a00m0na010000c.html?inb=rs |title = Former students sue ex-NOVA managers for unreturned tuition fees |accessdate = 18 October 2008 |publisher = [[Mainichi Daily News]] |date = 17 October 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081022033046/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/national/news/20081017p2a00m0na010000c.html?inb=rs |archivedate = 22 October 2008 |df = dmy }} == Lindsay Ann Hawker murder == {{main|Murder of Lindsay Hawker}} On 24 March 2007, [[Lindsay Hawker|Lindsay Ann Hawker]], a 22-year-old Nova teacher from Brandon near [[Coventry]], was murdered by 28-year-old Tatsuya Ichihashi. Her body was found three-days later in a sand-filled bathtub on the balcony of Ichihashi's apartment in [[Ichikawa, Chiba|Ichikawa]], [[Chiba Prefecture|Chiba]]. Police went to Ichihashi's apartment after Lindsay's flatmates had indicated she had gone there to teach an English lesson, but he managed to escape. He was captured in [[Osaka]] on 10 November 2009.[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/national/news/20091110p2a00m0na027000c.html Mainichi.jp] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091112104707/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/national/news/20091110p2a00m0na027000c.html |date=12 November 2009 }} He later confessed to the murder and was sentenced to life imprisonment.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article5139609.ece|archive-url=https://archive.is/20081120070202/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article5139609.ece|dead-url=yes|archive-date=20 November 2008|title=Bill Hawker: Where is my daughter's killer?|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|date=16 November 2008|accessdate=18 November 2008 | location=London}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|https://www.nova.co.jp}} {{Ja icon}} * [http://www.transpacificradio.com/2007/10/01/nova-employees-their-voices-their-stories/ Nova Employees: Their Voices, Their Stories], Ken Worsley, posted Monday, 1 October 2007 at ''Trans-Pacific Radio'' {{Eikaiwa}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nova (Eikaiwa)}} [[Category:English conversation schools in Japan]] [[Category:Companies based in Osaka Prefecture]] [[Category:Companies established in 1981]] [[Category:Japanese business law]] [[Category:Human rights in Japan]] [[Category:Companies that have filed for bankruptcy in Japan]]

revision.text:
'''OpenO&M (Open '''''O'''''perations and '''''M'''''aintenance)''' is an initiative of the following industry standards organisations: * [[International Society of Automation|The International Society of Automation (ISA)]] * Machinery Information Management Open System Alliance (MIMOSA) * [[Manufacturing Enterprise Solutions Association|Manufacturing Enterprise Solutions Association (MESA) International]] * [[OPC Foundation]] * Open Applications Group (OAGi)
The aim of OpenO&M is to provide a harmonized set of standards. From the organizational point of view, OpenO&M is a virtual organization maintained by MIMOSA.<ref>{{cite web|title=Analysis of Standards for Lifecycle Management of Systems for US Army --- a preliminary investigation|url=https://www.nist.gov/manuscript-publication-search.cfm?pub_id=822627|publisher=NIST|date=1 August 2006}}</ref>
==OpenO&M framework== The OpenO&M framework consists of the following standards for the exchange of Operations & Maintenance data and associated context: * MIMOSA Open System Architecture for [[Enterprise Application Integration]] (OSA-EAI) * MIMOSA Open System Architecture for [[Condition-based maintenance|Condition-Based Maintenance]] (OSA-CBM) based on ISO 13374<ref>{{cite web|title=Condition monitoring and diagnostics of machines -- Data processing, communication and presentation|url=http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue/catalogue_tc/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=21832|publisher=ISO|date=2003}}</ref> * [[ANSI/ISA-95]] – Enterprise/Control System Interface Standard * ISA-99 – Control System Cyber-Security Standard * ISA-OMAC – Open Modular Architecture Controls group standardizing packaging machinery interfaces * OPC interface specifications and data transport standards
==Joint working groups== OpenO&M is composed Joint Working Groups (JWG). These JWG are diverse groups of relevant organizations and subject matter experts. There are three Joint Working Groups: * Manufacturing JWG * Facilities JWG * Military JWG
The JWG are focused on enabling O&M application interoperability. The goal of the JWG is to offer domain end users a harmonized set of data exchange standards while avoiding duplication of work.<ref>{{cite web|title=OpenO&M|url=http://openoandm.org/}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.openoandm.org/ OpenO&M] * [http://www.isa.org/ ISA] * [http://www.mimosa.org MIMOSA] * [http://www.opcfoundation.org/ OPC Foundation]
{{DEFAULTSORT:OpenOandM}} [[Category:Maintenance]] [[Category:Logistics]] [[Category:Standards]]

revision.text:
In [[law]], the '''ordinary course of business''' covers the usual transactions, customs and practices of a certain business and of a certain firm. This term is used particularly to judge the validity of certain transactions. It is used in several different sections of the [[Uniform Commercial Code]] of the United States.
[https://www.law.cornell.edu/ucc/1/article1.htm#s1-201 Section 1-201 of the Uniform Commercial Code] defines a "Buyer in the ordinary course of business" by a four-part test:
# a person that buys goods in [[good faith]], # without knowledge that the sale violates the rights of another person in the goods <nowiki>[</nowiki>e.g. a [[security interest]]<nowiki>]</nowiki>, # and in the ordinary course from a person, other than a [[pawnbroker]], '''in the business of selling goods of that kind'''. # A person buys goods in the ordinary course if the sale to the person '''comports with the usual or customary practices''' in the kind of business in which the seller is engaged or with the seller's own usual or customary practices.
:<nowiki>[</nowiki>emphasis added<nowiki>]</nowiki>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ordinary Course Of Business}} [[Category:Legal terminology]] [[Category:Business law]]
{{Law-term-stub}}
